\chapter{\textcolor{Chapter }{LocalSNF package}}\logpage{[ 1, 0, 0 ]}
\hyperdef{L}{X7DD86B697CDC5E1F}{}
{
  
\section{\textcolor{Chapter }{Motivation}}\logpage{[ 1, 1, 0 ]}
\hyperdef{L}{X816FA3667FFEDC3F}{}
{
  Calculations of Smith Normal form with transformations are hard for large
matrices since the coefficients of the matix become extremely large. In some
situations it is sufficient to find Smoth Normal Form and transformation
matrices modulo power of a prime number. This package is developed to compute
Smith Normal Form with transformations for matrices over the ring
Z/2\texttt{\symbol{94}}N. The reduction algorithm is implemented in C for
speed-up purposes and ability to use multithreading and binary arithmetic
optimizations. }

 
\section{\textcolor{Chapter }{Functions}}\logpage{[ 1, 2, 0 ]}
\hyperdef{L}{X86FA580F8055B274}{}
{
  In this section we describe two functions implemented in this package. Both
functions take an optional parameter num{\textunderscore}threads for how many
threads to use in reduction algorithm. By default 4 threads are used. 

\subsection{\textcolor{Chapter }{SNFTransform}}
\logpage{[ 1, 2, 1 ]}\nobreak
\hyperdef{L}{X84D57A7D86DDCA1B}{}
{\noindent\textcolor{FuncColor}{$\triangleright$\enspace\texttt{SNFTransform({\mdseries\slshape mat, N})\index{SNFTransform@\texttt{SNFTransform}}
\label{SNFTransform}
}\hfill{\scriptsize (function)}}\\


 This function computes Smith Normal Form modulo 2\texttt{\symbol{94}}N of the
integral matrix mat. It returns record with fields: SNF,
row{\textunderscore}t, row{\textunderscore}t{\textunderscore}inverse,
col{\textunderscore}t, rank, power such that 
\begin{itemize}
\item  SNF is diagonal, its entries are powers of 2, and i entry divides i+1 entry
for all i
\item  SNF = row{\textunderscore}t * mat * col{\textunderscore}t mod
2\texttt{\symbol{94}}N
\item  row{\textunderscore}t * row{\textunderscore}t{\textunderscore}inverse = I,
rank is the rank of SNF, power = N 
\end{itemize}
 
\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=!@|,fontsize=\small,frame=single,label=Example]
  !gapprompt@gap>| !gapinput@SNFTransform([[1,2],[3,4]], 10: num_threads:=2);|
  rec( SNF := [ [ 1, 0 ], [ 0, 2 ] ], col_t := [ [ 1, 1022 ], [ 0, 1 ] ],
    power := 10, rank := 2, row_t := [ [ 1, 0 ], [ 515, 511 ] ],
    row_t_inverse := [ [ 1, 0 ], [ 3, 511 ] ] )
\end{Verbatim}
 \noindent\textcolor{FuncColor}{$\triangleright$\enspace\texttt{SaturationVectors({\mdseries\slshape mat, N})\index{SaturationVectors@\texttt{SaturationVectors}}
\label{SaturationVectors}
}\hfill{\scriptsize (function)}}\\


 This function a minimal set of vectors such that together with columns of mat
they span a direct summand of the module
(Z/2\texttt{\symbol{94}}N)\texttt{\symbol{94}}d where d is the number of rows
of mat. 
\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=!@|,fontsize=\small,frame=single,label=Example]
  !gapprompt@gap>| !gapinput@SaturationVectors([[1,2],[3,4]],10);|
  [ [ 0 ], [ 511 ] ]
\end{Verbatim}
 }

 }

 }
